questions.question: When is a blood sample taken to diagnose neonatal hypothyroidism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 72 hours after delivery Explanation: The blood sample taken for diagnosing neonatal hypothyroidism is 48-72 hours after delivery . Diagnosis: Primary hypothyroidism: T4 level: low TSH usually>100mIU/L Central hypothyroidism: Low TSH, T3, and T4 levels X-ray findings in congenital hypothyroidism: Absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphysis at birth Punctate epiphyseal dysgenesis Deformity or breaking of the 12th thoracic or 1st or 2nd lumbar vertebrae X-ray image of skull- large fontanelle and wide sutures Screening: Universal newborn screening for congenital hypothyroidism At birth, with umbilical cord blood (Option A) Diagnostic: Heel prick: dried blood spots, sample collected beyond 48 hrs or 48-72 hrs Should not be done in first 1-2 days, to avoid TSH surge (vs Option B and C) Most sensitive approach- check for T4 and TSH both ASH's first strategy: Initial TSH screening using dried blood spot If TSH>20mIU/L, recheck Obtain a venous blood sample to check T4 and TSH levels if TSH remains elevated. Treatment: Oral levothyroxine ( early morning with empty stomach for older children and for newborns; it is to be given at a fixed time) The dose is higher in the earlier age group, and as the babies grow, the dose reduces. Newborn- 10-15mg/kg/day Children- 2-4mg/kg/day Reference: O.P. Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Page 537-541, 676

questions.question: What condition is likely in a newborn presenting with dry, rough skin, a big tongue and rough hair?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Congenital hypothyroidism Explanation: Congenital hypothyroidism (also known as cretinism) presents with: Dry, rough skin Macroglossia (an enlarged, protruding tongue) Rough hair Congenital Hypothyroidism Clinical features Usually birth weight & length is normal Wide open anterior fontanelle Delayed closure of anterior fontanelle Prolonged physiological jaundice- Early sign (it is due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation) Myxedematous facies: Large, protruded tongue (Macroglossia) Cold intolerance Hypotonia Rough skin and Rough hair Constipation Abdominal distension Umbilical hernia In Untreated Cases: Delayed development Intellectual disability Delayed dentition Short stature Delayed puberty Delayed bone maturation X-ray findings in congenital hypothyroidism: Absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphysis at birth Punctate epiphyseal dysgenesis Deformity or breaking of the 12th thoracic or 1st or 2nd lumbar vertebrae X-ray image of skull- large fontanelle and wide sutures Screening: Universal newborn screening for congenital hypothyroidism At birth, with umbilical cord blood Heel prick: dried blood spots, sample collected beyond 48 hrs or 48-72hrs Should not be done in first 1-2 days, to avoid TSH surge Most sensitive approach- check for T4 and TSH both ASH's first strategy: Initial TSH screening using dried blood spot If TSH>20mIU/L, recheck Obtain a venous blood sample to check T4 and TSH levels if TSH remains elevated. Treatment Oral levothyroxine (early morning with empty stomach for older children; and for newborns, it is to be given at a fixed time). The dose is higher in the earlier age group and as the babies grow the dose reduces. Newborn- 10-15mg/kg/day Children- 2-4mg/kg/day Incorrect Options: Prader-Willi syndrome (Option B): This genetic disorder presents with poor feeding and hypotonia in infancy, followed by excessive eating and obesity in early childhood. It is also associated with intellectual disability & hypogonadism. It does not typically present with the skin, tongue, and hair changes. Edward syndrome (Option C): This chromosomal disorder (trisomy 18) presents with distinctive features, including rocker-bottom feet, overlapping fingers, cardiac anomalies, kidney malformations and microcephaly. The described skin and tongue manifestations are not typical features. Galactosemia (Option D): Galactosemia is characterized by jaundice, hepatomegaly, diarrhea, and vomiting. It does not cause the characteristic skin, tongue, and hair changes.

questions.question: A child with type 1 DM presents with acidosis, and blood sugar 400 mg/dl. What is the further management?

options.B: Normal saline with SC insulin stat
options.C: Normal saline followed by insulin infusion after 1 hour
options.D: Normal saline and insulin infusion immediately

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Normal saline followed by insulin infusion after 1 hour Explanation: The clinical scenario describes a child with type 1 diabetes mellitus (DM) presenting with acidosis and blood sugar 400 mg/dl, suggesting diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). Diabetic Ketoacidosis" data-author="" data-hash="11520" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/Mw0OKvq9qC8YpsgMGnTS1746179817.png" /> IV insulin stat (Option A): Administering IV insulin stat is not recommended in this scenario, as fluid resuscitation should be prioritized first. Insulin therapy should start at least 1 hour after fluid replacement to avoid complications like cerebral edema due to a rapid decrease in blood glucose. Normal saline with SC insulin stat (Option B): Subcutaneous insulin is not suitable for managing acute DKA. Intravenous insulin infusion is the preferred approach in this emergency setting as it provides more controlled glucose lowering. Normal saline and insulin infusion immediately (Option D): Starting insulin infusion immediately, without first addressing fluid resuscitation, can lead to a rapid drop in blood glucose. This might cause dangerous complications, including cerebral edema. Fluid replacement must be started before insulin infusion. Reference: ISPAD Pediatric Diabetes Guidelines 2022 https://cdn.ymaws.com/www.ispad.org/resource/resmgr/consensus_guidelines_2018_/guidelines2022/Ch.11 .

questions.question: A 3-week-old neonate presents with ambiguous genitalia with Na+ - 127, K+ - 6 meq/L with a BP of 50/22 mm Hg. Along with IV fluids, what specific management is done?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hydrocortisone Explanation: The clinical presentation of a neonate with ambiguous genitalia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypotension is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). Hydrocortisone is administered to manage the condition and address the cortisol deficiency. Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH): Cause: Over 90% of CAH cases are caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Hormone deficiency: Salt-wasting form: Deficiency in both aldosterone and cortisol. Simple virilizing form: Adequate aldosterone with excess adrenal androgens. Nonclassic form: Mildly elevated androgens, may be asymptomatic or show signs of androgen excess. Clinical Manifestations: Aldosterone and Cortisol Deficiency: Both hormones are deficient in the salt-wasting form (70% of cases). Symptoms: Weight loss, vomiting, dehydration, weakness, hypotension, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Prenatal Androgen Excess: Excess androgens during gestation lead to virilization in genetic females (46,XX), resulting in female pseudohermaphroditism. Features in affected females: Clitoromegaly, labial fusion, and formation of a urogenital sinus. The internal genitalia are typically normal, as there is no antimüllerian hormone secretion. Male infants (46,XY) appear normal at birth, delaying diagnosis until adrenal insufficiency develops. Postnatal Androgen Excess: Males: Enlarged penis with small prepubertal testes; potential for testicular adrenal rest tumors. Females: Progressive clitoromegaly and absence of menstruation or breast development unless treated. Adrenomedullary Dysfunction: Blunted epinephrine responses, hypoglycemia, and cardiovascular effects may exacerbate symptoms of cortisol deficiency in untreated cases. Laboratory Findings: Salt-Wasting Disease: Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and hypoglycemia. Hormonal Findings: Elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone, androstenedione, and testosterone (in females). ACTH Test: A marked increase in 17-hydroxyprogesterone after cosyntropin stimulation confirms the diagnosis. Treatment: Glucocorticoid Replacement Therapy : Replaces cortisol deficiency and suppresses excessive adrenal androgen production. Mineralocorticoid Replacement Therapy: Treats aldosterone deficiency in salt-wasting CAH. Additional Medical Approaches: Antiandrogens (e.g., flutamide): Block androgen effects. Aromatase inhibitors (e.g., anastrozole): Slow skeletal maturation by inhibiting androgen-to-estrogen conversion. Growth hormone therapy: May enhance adult height. Surgical Management: Clitoral reduction (if severe clitoromegaly). Vaginoplasty and urogenital sinus correction. Reference: Nelson Textbook of Paediatrics, 21st Edition, Page 2971-2977 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3242885/#

questions.question: The mother brought her 3-year-old daughter to seek medical attention due to the girl's enlarged clitoris. The results of the karyotype test showed a 46XX pattern. What is the probable underlying cause for this condition? α -OH deficiency
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 21 hydroxylase deficiency Explanation: In individuals with XX chromosomes (typically female), the excess androgens due to 21 hydroxylase deficiency can cause virilization of the external genitalia, resulting in an enlarged clitoris. 21 hydroxylase deficiency characterized by impaired production of cortisol and aldosterone leads to an increase in adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) secretion, which stimulates the adrenal glands to produce excess androgens (male sex hormones). 21-Hydroxylase Deficiency Most common form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) (90%) Enzyme Affected: 21-hydroxylase Pathogenesis 21-hydroxylase deficiency impairs the synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone. Low cortisol levels lead to elevated ACTH levels. Elevated ACTH causes the accumulation of steroid precursors, including dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA), androstenedione, and 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP). Clinical Manifestations Salt wasting form: Severe deficiency with nearly absent enzyme activity. Presents in neonates with salt-wasting, virilization, ambiguous genitalia in girls, failure to thrive, polyuria, hyperpigmentation, critical electrolyte imbalances and shock. Diagnosis may be missed in boys. Simple virilizing form: Partial enzyme activity (25%) allows aldosterone production. Features include virilization in girls and peripheral precocious puberty in boys . Non-classic form: Mild enzyme deficiency with mild hyperandrogenism. Symptoms include hirsutism, acne, and menstrual irregularities in adolescents. Diagnosis Salt-Wasting Form: Extreme elevations of 17-OHP levels (10000-20000 ng/dL, normal <200 ng/dL) in the context of clinical signs of adrenal insufficiency. Simple Virilizing and Non Classic Forms: Elevated 17-OHP levels measured before and 60 minutes after an intramuscular ACTH injection (0.25 mg). Treatment Salt wasting and virilizing forms treated with Hydrocortisone (10-15 mg/m²/day) and Fludrocortisone (0.1 mg/day). Long-acting glucocorticoid preparations (dexamethasone or prednisolone) may be used after growth and puberty are complete. 11 hydroxylase deficiency (Option B) is another form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), but it typically leads to hypertension and may cause ambiguous genitalia and hypokalemia. It is less commonly associated with an enlarged clitoris. 3 beta dehydrogenase deficiency (Option C) is a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) characterized by impaired conversion of pregnenolone to progesterone. It can lead to impaired production of cortisol and aldosterone, but it is not typically associated with virilization and an enlarged clitoris. 17 α -OH deficiency (Option D) is generally present with complaints of delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea and a lack of secondary sexual characteristics in a female patient. The presentation in male patients is typically under masculinization and can range from phenotypic females to ambiguous or small male genitalia.

questions.question: What could be a potential cause for a child with short stature who is brought to the pediatrician and has high growth hormone levels and low insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C- Laron dwarfism Explanation: The clinical manifestations indicate Laron dwarfism , also known as growth hormone insensitivity syndrome . This rare genetic disorder is characterized by the paradoxical combination of elevated growth hormone levels with low IGF-1 levels, resulting from mutations in the growth hormone receptor gene or post-receptor signaling pathway. Despite high circulating levels of growth hormone, the body's inability to respond to it leads to inadequate IGF-1 production, which is essential for normal growth and development. Incorrect Options: Turner syndrome (Option A): Growth hormone treatment is often used to help girls with Turner Syndrome achieve greater height. The underlying cause of short stature in Turner Syndrome is related to the SHOX gene, not growth hormone deficiency. Also, this condition is associated with other characteristic features, such as webbed neck and ovarian dysgenesis, which are not mentioned in this case. Pituitary dwarfism (Option B): This condition, also known as growth hormone deficiency, is characterized by low growth hormone levels and subsequent low IGF-1 levels. The presentation of high growth hormone levels, in this case, makes pituitary dwarfism an unlikely diagnosis. Maternal deprivation dwarfism (Option D): This psychosocial condition occurs in infants due to severe emotional deprivation or neglect. While it can cause growth failure and stunting, it does not present with the specific hormonal pattern of high growth hormone and low IGF-1 levels. Reference: O.P. Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Page 535.

questions.question: A 22-year-old mother presented with her 2-week-old newborn who had a large tongue and an umbilical hernia. Which of the following investigations has to be done in view of congenital hypothyroidism?

options.A: A fresh blood sample and screen first for TSH levels
options.B: A fresh blood sample and screen first for T4 levels
options.C: A dried blood sample and screen first for TSH levels
options.D: A dried blood sample and screen first for T4 levels

questions.explanation: Correct Answer C- A dried blood sample and screen first for TSH levels Explanation: The clinical manifestations indicate congenital hypothyroidism, as evidenced by the large tongue and umbilical hernia . The screening method for congenital hypothyroidism involves using dried blood spot samples and testing for TSH levels . TSH is a more sensitive and specific marker for detecting hypothyroidism in newborns Elevated TSH levels indicate hypothyroidism, while low or normal TSH levels suggest normal thyroid function Measuring T4 levels alone is not sufficient (Option B and C Ruled Out) for the initial screening of congenital hypothyroidism because T4 levels can be affected by various factors, including stress, illness, and medications Dried blood spot testing is a simple, minimally invasive method to collect a blood sample , allowing for large-scale newborn screening programs where a small amount of blood from a heel prick is readily accessible for analysis. (Option A Ruled Out) Congenital Hypothyroidism Definition Most common preventable cause of intellectual disability Prevalence of 1 in 2,000 newborns Results from defects in hypothalamic-pituitary axis or thyroid gland Can be congenital or acquired Etiology Thyroid dysgenesis (75% of cases) Spectrum ranging from agenesis to ectopic thyroid Biosynthetic defects affecting iodine transport, peroxidation, thyroglobulin synthesis Pendred syndrome (associated with decreased intracellular transport of iodine and deafness) Genetic defects associated with TSHR, PAX8, and TSHB genes Clinical Features Congenital Signs: Open posterior fontanel Umbilical hernia Delayed neurodevelopment Large tongue Common Features: Growth retardation Sallow edematous facies Delayed skeletal maturation Delayed dental eruption Delayed puberty Constipation Myopathy and pseudohypertrophy Hypothermia Screening Dried blood spot (DBS) sample at age 2-4 days Screen first for TSH levels TSH thresholds for treatment: >20 mU/L in first week >10 mU/L between 7-21 days >6 mU/L beyond 21 days Investigations I nitial Tests: Serum TSH and FT4 levels TSH > 20 mU/L in first week needs evaluation Further Evaluation: Radionuclide scan Ultrasound of thyroid Children with undetectable thyroid may need testing for: Defects in iodine transport TSH receptor abnormalities TSH blocking antibody Management Immediate thyroxine replacement after diagnosis Dosage: 10-15 µ g/kg/day In central hypothyroidism, cortisol replacement should precede thyroid replacement Monitor FT4 and TSH levels every 2 months in first year Long-term follow-up required Most children require lifelong therapy Reference: OP Ghai Essential Paediatrics 10th Edition, Page 538-539

questions.question: What specific actions are taken for the management of a 3-week-old neonate with ambiguous genitalia, a sodium level of 127, a potassium level of 6 meq, and a blood pressure of 50/22 mm Hg, in addition to administering intravenous fluids?
questions.explanation: sodium level, a high serum potassium level, and a low BP is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. CAH is a group of autosomal recessive disorders characterized by impaired cortisol synthesis, leading to an accumulation of precursors and subsequent adrenal gland hyperplasia. The most common enzyme deficiency causing CAH is 21-hydroxylase deficiency. In a neonate with CAH, the low cortisol levels lead to an overproduction of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which stimulates the adrenal glands to produce excess androgens. This can result in ambiguous genitalia in females and precocious pseudopuberty in males. The specific management in this case involves administration of hydrocortisone, a glucocorticoid, to replace the deficient cortisol and suppress the excessive ACTH production. Hydrocortisone helps to normalize electrolyte imbalances, such as hyponatremia and hyperkalemia, and improve blood pressure. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Wide open posterior fontanelle, large tongue, rough dry skin with constipation is seen in:
questions.explanation: fontanelle, large tongue, rough dry skin, and constipation is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. Incorrect Options: Option A - Pellagra: Pellagra is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of niacin (vitamin B3). It typically presents with symptoms such as dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Option B - Down syndrome: Down syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21. Option D - Nutritional rickets: Nutritional rickets is a condition caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to impaired bone mineralization. It is characterized by skeletal deformities, such as bowed legs. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Which of the following is produced in the highest amounts by the fetal adrenal gland ?
questions.explanation: producing various hormones that are important for growth and development. Among these hormones, DHEA is produced in the highest amounts by the fetal adrenal glands. DHEA (dehydroepiandrosterone) is an androgen hormone and a precursor to other sex hormones, such as testosterone and estrogen. It is primarily produced by the zona reticularis layer of the adrenal cortex. In the fetus, DHEA is synthesized from cholesterol, and its production increases as the pregnancy progresses. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are produced in relatively lower as compared to the DHEA Reference: Prepladder Notes
